title: Newcastle property firm LSL boost profits after selling off Zoopla shares
text:
Newcastle property firm LSL boost profits after selling off Zoopla shares The firm behind the Your Move and Reed Rains brands said 2017 has started positively Share LSL property services has marked a successful year (Photo: pa) Share Get business   Thank you for subscribing!   
Newcastle-headquartered property firm LSL Property Services has toasted a strong year of trading, growing operating profit by 58% to top £65.4m. 
The firm said it had delivered a solid performance in a changing market in the year ended December 31 2016, delivering sales of £307.8m, up 2% on the previous year. 
Pre-tax profit soared by 65% from £38.6m to £63.5m and the firm also made an exceptional gain of £32.9m on sale of its Zoopla shares. 
LSL, which operates 12 estate agency brands including Your Move and Reeds Rains, said the overall UK residential property services market last year was impacted by two main events – the EU referendum and its impact on consumer confidence, and the lead up to the stamp duty changes on April 1 2016 which saw those buying a second home facing a 3% increase in Stamp Duty Land Tax. 
Consumer confidence was knocked after the Brexit vote , the firm said, and volumes fell by 12.4% in the third quarter compared to the same period in 2015. Volumes fell again by 4.8% in the fourth quarter of 2016 compared to the same period in 2015. 
LSL said it saw a notable acceleration of transactions in first quarter of the year as the change in stamp duty regulations loomed, and that it “reacted decisively to the changing market conditions” in the second half of the year. 
It paused its acquisition activity and carried out selective cost reduction measures, closing 21 of its 540 branches across the UK, including four in the North East. 
Overall, headcount was reduced from 5,181 to 4,991 but it invested in its lettings and financial services departments during the second half of the year, delivering growth of 9% in the lettings business and a 27% revenue rise in financial services. 
Looking ahead, LSL said the year has started positively in both divisions lettings and estate agencies, but that house sale volumes are expected to drop by around 4%. Read More Mike Ashley's retail empire Sports Direct warns of currency impact 
Group chief executive Ian Crabb said that while it was difficult to predict consumer confidence for the rest of the year, conditions were good, and the North East has a positive outlook for the year ahead. 
He said: “In terms of consumers the good news is that mortgage availability is very positive so that good news. Mortgage rates that consumers are paying are at historically low levels, and broadly the outlook for the UK economy is reasonably positive. 
“Our avergae operating profit per branch across the estate agencies was £30,000 and our strategy is to get that to £80,000 to £100,000. Our two main levers to do that are to continue to grow lettings revenues and continuing to grow financial services, and if we can be a little more cost effective we will look to do that. 
“It’s more about evolution not revolution, we’re not looking at major restructuring.” Read More Newcastle technology giant Sage buys HR specialists Fairsail 
Chairman Simon Embley added: “Following a strong first half performance, the group delivered a resilient second half performance given the changing market conditions. I am pleased that we maintained revenue growth in both the estate agency and surveying divisions. 
“The group reacted decisively to the changing market conditions in the second half by taking selective cost measures and strengthening the balance sheet. 
“The business is well positioned to capitalise on market conditions to increase shareholder value.” Like us on Facebook
